introduction.p:
A device that does a conversion of heat to some other form of energy in a continuous process is called a heat engine. A heat engine must work in a cyclic process for the engine to convert heat to work continuously. shows the energy cycle of a heat engine schematically. As shown in this figure, an engine interacts with three external bodies.
The engine takes in energy Q_H from a hot bath, such as a furnace.
The engine produces work W through some mechanical apparatus, such as turbine which normally converts the mechanical energy to the electrical energy.
Finally, the engine gives up energy Q_C to a cold bath, such as cold water, in order to return to the initial state and complete the cycle. That is, the cycle could not make use of all the energy in Q_H in order for it to run in a cycle.

figure.caption: Schematics of energy flow in and out of a heat engine. The heat engine works in a cyclic process, returning to the same energy state at the end of each cycle, hence, \Delta U = 0. During one cycle, the engine's energy goes up and down as energy flowsin and out of the engine. In a typical heat engine, the energy first goes up by Q_H, then decreases by W, and then decreases further by Q_C before returning to the starting state.

introduction.p:
At the end of each cycle, the engine returns to the initial state, therefore, the net change in the internal energy of the engine must be zero. In each cycle, engine takes up energy Q_H and gives up energy W+Q_C. Therefore, work by the engine would be the difference of heat in and heat out.
W = Q_H - Q_C,
where all quantities are positive. The efficiency of a heat engine \eta is defined as the ratio of the amount of net work W the engine produces in one cycle to the amount of heat Q_H transferred to the engine from the heat source.
\eta = \frac{W}{Q_H}.
Putting the expression of W from Eq. , the efficiency of a heat engine can he rewritten as follows.
\eta = \frac{Q_H - Q_C}{Q_H} = 1- \frac{ Q_C}{Q_H}.
Clearly if all of heat taken (Q_H) is converted into work, i.e. if Q_C = 0, the efficiency will be 1, corresponding to a 100%-efficient engine. Experience has shown that this is not possible. We will study next an ideal engine called the Carnot engine that places an absolute limit on the highest possible efficiency of a heat engine.

statement.p: In a steam engine, a fixed amount of water is the working substance which goes through a full cycle, from liquid water at a certain temperature and pressure to steam, and then back to the liquid water at the original temperature and pressure.

The heat is put in the working substance, which is water here, in the step when liquid water is converted to steam. In some other parts of the cycle the steam expands and the energy comes out of steam when the steam pushes on the blades of a turbine, and in some other parts, the water has to be pumped and compressed, which requires work also.

In a certain steam engine, net work done by the working substance of the engine was 2000 J per cycle. If the efficiency of the steam engine is 40%, how much heat must be rejected in the cooling part of the cycle?

solution.p:
The net work W by the engine and the efficiency \eta of the engine are given here and we need to find Q_C. From the efficiency \eta and work W, we can find Q_H, and then using the energy balance, we will find Q_C.
\eta = \frac{W}{Q_H}\ \ \Longrightarrow\ \ Q_H = \frac{W}{\eta} = \frac{2000\ \text{J}}{0.4} = 5000\ \text{J}.
Now, from the energy balance over one cycle, we know that in an engine, W = Q_H-Q_C. Therefore,
Q_C = Q_H-W = 5000\ \text{J}- 2000\ \text{J} = 3000\ \text{J}.

exercise.title: Work Produced and Efficiecy of a Thermal Engine

statement.p: A heat engine operates between two temperatures such that the working substance of the engine absorbs 5000 J of heat from the high temperature bath and rejects 3000 J to the low temperature bath. The rest of the energy is converted into the mechanical energy of the turbine.
(a) Find the amount of work produced by the engine.
(b) Find the efficiency of the engine.

hint.p: (a) In a cycle W = Q. (b) Efficiency = Work/Heat in.

solution.p:
(a) First we note that in a cycle \Delta U = 0. That means, in a cycle
W_\text{net,by} = Q_\text{net}.
Taking engine as the system. That will make Q_\text{in} \gt 0 and Q_\text{out} \lt 0. That will give
Q_\text{net} = 5000\text{ J} - 3000\text{ J} = 2000\text{ J}.
Therefore,
W_\text{net,by} = 2000\text{ J}.

(b) The efficiency is the work by the engine divided by the heat into the engine at higher temperature.
\eta = \frac{W_{by}}{Q_{in}} = \dfrac{2000\text{ J}}{5000\text{ J}} = 0.4.
As a percentage, it is 40%.

exercise.title: Efficiency of a Coal Power Plant

statement.p: A coal power plant consumes 100,000 kg of coal per hour and produces 500 MW of power. If the heat of combustion of coal is 30 MJ/kg, what is the efficiency of the power plant?

hint.p: Use Q=mh to get the energy produced by burning coal.

solution.p:
From the mass m and the heat of combustion h of coal we get Q_{in}. In one hour the heat entering the system at high temperature of the cycle is
Q_{in}[\textrm{1 hour}] \amp = m h \amp = 10^5\ \textrm{kg}\times 30\ \textrm{MJ/kg} = 3\times 10^6\ \textrm{MJ}.
The power produced is the work produced per unit time. The data is given in the unit $MW$, which is MJ/s. In one hour the work produced will be
W_{by} = 500\ \textrm{MW} \times 3600\ \textrm{s} = 1.8\times 10^6\ \textrm{MJ}.
Therefore,
\textrm{Efficiency} \amp = \frac{W_{by}}{Q_{in}} \amp = \frac{1.8\times 10^6\ \textrm{MJ}}{3\times 10^6\ \textrm{MJ}} = 0.6.
This is 60%.
